div.note: Although most people were streaming in from the opposite end of the valley, our three refugees started to run into fellow travelers and fellows in misfortune, who had entered or were entering the main road from various crossroads and footpaths. Any person you meet in such circumstances seems like an old acquaintance. Every time the cart pulled alongside a pedestrian, questions and answers were exchanged.
Some, like our protagonists, had fled without waiting for the soldiers to arrive. Some had heard their trumpets and drums. And some had seen them, depicting them as the terrified are wont to depict.
“We’ve been lucky,” said the two women, “thank heavens.
Who cares about our things? At least we’re safe.”
But Don Abbondio found little to be happy about. Indeed, that confluence of people, especially the greater numbers he could hear arriving from the opposite end of the valley, was making him wary.
“What is going on here?” he grumbled to the women when they were alone for a moment. “What is going on?

Don’t you realize that gathering so many people in one place is practically begging the soldiers to come? With all the hiding and removal of things, nothing’s left in the houses. They’re going to think there’s treasure up there.
They will surely be coming: Surely they will. Woe is me! What have I gotten myself into?”
“The last thing they’ll want to do is go up there,” said Perpetua. “They’ve got other places to be.
And I’ve always heard that, in times of danger, there’s safety in numbers.”
“In numbers? In numbers?” replied Don Abbondio. “Poor woman!
Don’t you know that a single Landsknecht could eat a hundred of us for lunch?
And then, if they do go rogue, we’ll get caught in the middle!
Oh, poor me!
We’d have been better off going up the mountains!
Why did everyone have to rush toward the same place!…What pests!” he grumbled in a lower voice. “They’re all here: rush, rush, rush. One after the other, like mindless sheep.”
“That’s what you think,” said Agnese, “but they could say the same thing about us.”
“Shush,” said Don Abbondio. “Enough with all this chatter.
What’s done is done. We’re here, and here we stay.
It’s up to Providence now. May God help us.”

But things got even worse at the entrance to the valley, where he saw a group of armed men milling about the doorway and ground floor of a house: It looked like a barracks. He glanced at them out of the corner of his eye; these didn’t look like the same faces he had seen on his previous stressful trip, or if some were, they had changed considerably. Nonetheless, he was distressed beyond words by the sight.
“Poor me!” he thought. “What if they get violent?
And how could they not? I should have expected as much from a man like him.
What does he want to do? To wage war? To be king? Him? Poor me! When everyone is just trying to find a hole in which to hide, he’s doing his best to be conspicuous.
You’d think he wanted to invite them in!”
“Now, master, you can see for yourself,” Perpetua said, “look at the brave men we have here.
They’ll know how to defend us from the German soldiers; not like the scaredy-cats we’ve got back home, who are good for nothing except heading for the hills.”
“Shush!” replied Don Abbondio, in a low but angry voice. “Shush! You don’t know what you’re talking about.
Pray to heaven those soldiers are in a hurry, or that they don’t find out what’s going on up here. This place is being turned into a fortress.
Don’t you know it’s a soldier’s job to take fortresses?
They like nothing better! Launching an attack, going to a wedding: It’s all the same to them. Everything they touch instantly belongs to them, and they’ll run people through with their swords.
Woe is me!
Anyway. I’ll see if there’s a way to get us up these cliffs to safety.
They won’t catch me in a battle. Oh, no, they won’t.”
“Well, if you’re afraid of being defended and helped,” Perpetua started to say, but Don Abbondio interrupted her in a harsh, low voice: “Shush!
I’m warning you not to repeat what I said.
Remember that while we’re here, we have to keep a smile on our faces and agree with everything we see.”
At the Malanotte, they found another group of armed men. Don Abbondio tipped his hat to them, while thinking, “Woe is me. I’m in the belly of the beast!”
Here the cart came to a stop, and they got out. Don Abbondio paid quickly and sent the driver on his way. He started walking up the hill with his two companions without saying a word.
The sight of these familiar places, combined with his present fears, reawakened the memory of his sufferings the last time he had been here.

And Agnese, who had never laid eyes on the area, imagined a nightmarish scenario whenever she thought of Lucia’s harrowing ordeal. She felt a new and sharper sense of those cruel memories now that she saw the castle.
“Oh, Reverend!” she exclaimed. “To think that my poor Lucia went up this road!”
“Will you be quiet, you silly woman!” Don Abbondio shouted in her ear. “Is that anything to say at a time like this?
Don’t you realize we’re at his home?
You’re lucky no one heard you just now. But if you keep talking this way…”
“Oh!” said Agnese. “But now that he’s a saint…!”
“Be quiet!” Don Abbondio repeated. “Do you think you can tell a saint anything you want, showing him no regard? What you really should be thinking about is how you’ll thank him for all his kindness!”
“Well, I already have; do you think I don’t know a thing or two about proper etiquette?”
“Proper etiquette is not saying anything that might upset someone, especially someone who’s not used to hearing criticism.
You both need to understand that this is no place for gossip or blurting out everything that pops into your head.

It’s the house of a great nobleman, as you already know. Look at the company we’re in: These are people from all walks of life. So use your heads, if you’re capable. Weigh your words, and above all, speak little, and only when necessary. With your mouth shut you’ll never be wrong.”
“You’re much worse with all your—” Perpetua started to retort.
“Be quiet,” Don Abbondio hissed under his breath, at the same time as he quickly doffed his hat and made a deep bow. For as he looked up, he spotted the Nameless One walking downhill toward them.
The nobleman had also seen and recognized Don Abbondio, and he quickened his step to meet him.
“Reverend Father,” he said as he drew near, “I wish I was offering you hospitality on a better occasion, but I am still very happy to be of some service.”

“Trusting in the great generosity of your most illustrious Lordship,” replied Don Abbondio, “I have been so bold as to come, in these unhappy circumstances, to inconvenience you. And as your most illustrious Lordship can see, I have also taken the liberty of bringing some company with me.
This is my housekeeper…”
“Welcome,” said the Nameless One.
“And this,” Don Abbondio continued, “is a woman your Lordship has already been good to: the mother of that…of that…”
“Of Lucia,” said Agnese.
“Of Lucia!” exclaimed the Nameless One, who turned to Agnese, bowing his head.
“Me? Good?
Lord God!
It is you who are being good to me by coming here…to me…to this home.
You are most welcome.
You are the one bestowing your blessing on us.”
“Oh, yes,” said Agnese. “I am coming to inconvenience you.”
Then she added, whispering in his ear, “I also have to thank you…”
The Nameless One interrupted her, inquiring anxiously for news of Lucia. He then turned to accompany his new guests up to the castle, which he did, despite their protests.
Agnese gave the priest a look as if to say, “Do you really think there was any need to stick your nose in with your advice?”
“Have they already reached your parish?” the Nameless One asked him.
“No, sir, but I did not want to sit around waiting for those devils,” replied Don Abbondio.
“If I had, heaven knows whether I would have made it out alive, to come and inconvenience your illustrious Lordship.”
“Well, take heart,” the Nameless One resumed, “now you’re safe.
They won’t be coming up here. And if they try, we’re ready for them.”
“Let’s hope they don’t come,” said Don Abbondio.
“And I hear,” he added, pointing at the mountains rising on the opposite end of the valley, “I hear that, over there, the other troops are roaming, but…but…”
“True,” said the Nameless One. “But don’t worry, we’re ready for them, too.”
“Between a rock and a hard place,” thought Don Abbondio. “Right between a rock and a hard place.
How did I end up here? Blame it on those two chatterboxes!
And he seems to be reveling in it!
What is wrong with the people of this world?”

After they entered the castle, the nobleman directed Agnese and Perpetua to a room in the quarter assigned to women, which took up three sides of the second courtyard, in the rear of the building. It stood on an isolated rock jutting out over a cliff.
The men were lodged on the right and left sides of the other courtyard, which looked out on the terrace.

The two courtyards were connected by a wide corridor facing the main gate, which served as a storage area for food supplies and any belongings that the refugees might have brought with them for safekeeping.
In the men’s quarter, there were a few rooms set aside for members of the clergy.
The Nameless One took it upon himself to accompany Don Abbondio, who was the first to take possession of them.
For twenty-three or twenty-four days, our refugees stayed in the castle, surrounded by constant motion and a crowd of people that kept growing initially, though nothing out of the ordinary happened.
Scarcely a day went by without an alarm being sounded.
The Landsknechts are coming! The cappelletti have been spotted!
At every alarm, the Nameless One sent his men out to investigate, and, if trouble was found, he would leave the valley with the men he kept on the alert, and go to where the danger had been reported.
They were a sight to behold: a brigade of men armed from head to toe, marching in military formation, but led by an unarmed man.
Usually all they found were random foragers and looters who would flee before they could be caught.
But once, while chasing away some looters as a warning to never come back, the Nameless One received news that a nearby village had been invaded and sacked.

Landsknechts from various divisions had lingered behind to plunder, joining forces and staging surprise attacks on territories near where the army was quartered. They would rob the inhabitants of their possessions and subject them to every kind of outrage.
The Nameless One gave a short speech to his men and led them to the village.
Their arrival was unexpected.

The rogues, who had thought they could make easy work of looting, found themselves instead under attack by men in battle formation, ready to fight. They dropped everything and fled without waiting for one another, heading back in the direction from which they had come.
The Nameless One chased them part of the way. Then, calling a halt, he lingered for a bit to see if there were any further developments. Finally, he ordered the return home.
As he went back through the rescued village, you cannot imagine the applause and the thanks that greeted the troop of liberators and their leader.
At the castle, among the jumbled multitude of people of various classes, customs, ages, and sexes, there was never any major conflict.
The Nameless One had posted guards at multiple locations, to make sure that no disturbances occurred, and each did his job with the care required when one is held accountable.
He then asked the clergymen and the most authoritative men among the refugees to make the rounds and help keep an eye on things.

He himself also made the rounds as often as he could and made sure he was seen everywhere. But even in his absence, a reminder of whose house they were staying in helped to control those who might need to be controlled.

They were refugees, after all, and therefore generally more inclined to be peaceful; thoughts of their homes and belongings, and—for some—of family or friends still in danger, as well as the news that kept arriving, dampened their spirits and maintained and increased that disposition.
There were a few carefree types, men with a steadier temperament and youthful energy, who tried to pass the days more cheerfully.

They had abandoned their homes because they were not strong enough to defend them, but they saw no point in sighing and crying over things that couldn’t be fixed, or in imagining and contemplating the devastation they would unfortunately see with their own eyes.
Close families had traveled to the castle together, or met up there, and new friendships had been formed. The guests split into groups by disposition and customs.

The ones with money and discretion went to eat down in the valley, where a few taverns had sprung up to meet the moment’s needs. In some of these taverns, mouthfuls alternated with sighs, and disasters were the only topic of conversation; in others, disaster was never mentioned, except for advice to avoid thinking about it.

For those unable or unwilling to buy their food outside, bread, soup, and wine were distributed in the castle. A few tables were also prepared every day for guests whom the master had specially invited. And our three friends were among this number.

Agnese and Perpetua, who did not want a free meal, asked to be employed in the services that such large-scale hospitality required. So this is how they spent most of their day. The rest of the time they spent chatting with the other women or with Don Abbondio.
Although he had nothing to do, he wasn’t bored: Fear kept him company.

He had gotten over any fear of an attack, I believe; if any did remain, it was the least of his worries, since, if he thought about it even a tiny bit, he must have realized that his fears were baseless.

But, beyond agonizing over his poor house, he was beset by a constant, vague, general terror at the image of the surrounding country swarming with vicious soldiers, the sight of arms and armed men always and everywhere, the castle—that castle!—and the fear that, given the circumstances, anything could happen, at any moment.

During his entire stay in that refuge, he never went farther than a stone’s throw outside, and never once set foot on the path down the hill. The only walk he took was on the terrace, or from one end of the castle to the other, to look down the cliffs and ravines, and examine whether there might be some viable pathway, a mountain trail that might help him find a hiding place in the event of hand-to-hand combat.

He paid great respects and gave warm greetings to all his fellow refugees, but he associated with only a few. His most frequent conversations were with the two women, as I have mentioned. With them he let off steam, at the risk of a scolding from Perpetua and a shaming from Agnese.

At the communal table, where he spent little time and spoke even less, he heard the news of the terrifying march, which arrived daily, reported from village to village and mouth to mouth, or brought to them by someone who had initially tried to stay home but ultimately fled, without managing to save anything, and, to make matters worse, was beaten black and blue. Every day brought a new tale of catastrophe.
Some, storytellers by profession, diligently collected all the rumors, sifted through them, and conveyed their essence to the others.

There were debates over which regiment was more ferocious, and whether the infantry or the cavalry was worse. They would recite, as best they could, the names of certain leaders and relate their exploits, specifying where they had stopped and where they had marched. On such and such a day, this regiment or that invaded this or that village, and tomorrow they would attack others, and in the meantime yet another regiment had raised hell and worse.

Above all, the storytellers scrambled to get information and keep track of the regiments that crossed the Lecco bridge, one after the other, so they could mark them off as departed, and gone from the area for good.

The Wallenstein cavalry passed, then the Merode infantry, then the Anhalt cavalry, then the Brandenburg infantry, the Montecuccoli and Ferrari cavalry. Then the Altringer, Fürstenberg, and Colloredo all passed, followed by the Croatians and the Conti. More and more passed and finally, when it pleased the heavens, so did Gallas.
The flying squadron of the Venetians finally left, as well, and the whole region, from right to left, was free.

The people from the first areas invaded and evacuated had already left the castle, and more were departing every day, like birds after an autumn storm, scattering from the leafy branches of the big tree in which they had sought shelter and flying off in every direction.

Our three friends were among the last to go, I believe. And this at the wish of Don Abbondio, who feared, if he returned home immediately, that he would find stray Landsknechts who had lingered behind in the wake of the passing army.

Perpetua gave him a piece of her mind, saying the longer they waited, the freer local rascals would feel to enter their house and carry away anything that was left. But when it came to saving his skin, Don Abbondio always won the argument, unless the proximity of danger made him lose his wits entirely.
On the day of their departure, the Nameless One ordered a carriage for them at the Malanotte. In it, he had placed a new set of linen for Agnese.

Taking her aside, he pressed her to accept a purse filled with scudi, which she could use to repair the damage she would find at home, despite her protests, beating her breast, and assuring him that she still had some left over from his last gift.

“When you see your poor, good Lucia,” he said at last, “who I know is already praying for me, please tell her, since I did her so much wrong, that I am grateful, and that I trust in God her prayers will also bestow many blessings on her.”
He insisted on accompanying all three down to the carriage.
I will allow the reader to imagine the humble, groveling thank-yous of Don Abbondio and the compliments of Perpetua.

Finally, they left. As planned, they made a short stop at the tailor’s cottage, but did not stay long enough to sit. There they heard a hundred stories about the army’s passage: the usual tales of robberies, beatings, vandalism, and filth. But no Landsknechts, thank goodness, had been sighted in that area.
“Oh, Reverend!” said the tailor, helping him back up into the carriage. “After a disaster like this, there’s enough material for a few books!”

A little bit farther down the road, our travelers started to see with their own eyes some of the things they had heard described: vineyards picked clean, not like in the harvest but as if struck by a combination of hail and hurricane—shoots torn away and scattered everywhere; fenceposts ripped out; the ground trampled and strewn with splinters, leaves, and twigs; trees uprooted or stripped of their branches; gaps in the hedges and gates destroyed.

And then in the villages, doorways had been broken down, windows smashed, and straw, rags, and rubbish of every kind was amassed or strewn on the road. The air was thick, and wafts of an even worse stench drifted out from the houses. Some people were tossing out the filth, others were fixing the shutters as best they could, and still others commiserated in groups. As the carriage passed, hands stretched out toward the window from every side, begging for charity.

With these images before their eyes one second, and in their minds the next, as well as the expectation that they would find more of the same at home, they arrived and found, in fact, exactly what they had been expecting.

Agnese set her bundles down in a corner of her little yard, which was now the cleanest spot in her home, and immediately started sweeping, gathering and putting into order the few things she had left. She sent for a carpenter and a blacksmith to repair the worst of the damages, and then, inspecting her new linens piece by piece, and counting the new coins, she said to herself, “I’ve landed on my feet. Blessed be the Lord and the Madonna and that kind gentleman.
I really can say that I’ve landed on my feet.”

Don Abbondio and Perpetua did not need keys to enter their house.With every step down the hall, an odor grew stronger—fetid, poisonous, pestilential—and turned their stomachs. Holding their noses, they headed toward the kitchen doorway. Entering on tiptoe, they examined the floor to see where they could set their feet down, avoiding as best they could the filth that covered it. They took a long look around.

Nothing had been left in one piece. In every corner of that room and the rest of the house, all they could see were bits and pieces of things that used to be: quills and feathers from Perpetua’s hens, strips of bed linen, paper torn from Don Abbondio’s calendars, shards of broken pots and plates, all in heaps or strewn around the room.
In the fireplace, they could see the vestiges of wholesale looting, jumbled together, like the too many ideas underlying the prose of a stylish writer.

These were, as I was saying, the remains of spent charcoal and embers that, upon closer inspection, turned out to have been the arm of a chair, the leg of a table, the door of a cabinet, the slat of a bed, the stave of the barrel that used to hold the wine that settled poor Don Abbondio’s stomach.

All the rest was ashes and charcoal. And with these same bits of charcoal, the looters, for fun, had scribbled stick figures on the wall, trying—by adding birettas or tonsures and wide bands—to make them look like priests, taking great pains to make them horrible and ridiculous: a goal, to tell the truth, that was easy to achieve for such artists.
“What pigs!” exclaimed Perpetua.
“What scoundrels!” exclaimed Don Abbondio. As if to escape, they ran outside through the garden door.

They caught their breath, and then went straight to the fig tree. Before they even reached it, they saw that the ground had been freshly dug, and they both cried out at once. When they got there, they found not the body but the empty grave.

And here a squabble began. Don Abbondio started to blame Perpetua for not burying his valuables properly. And do you think she held back? After shouting at each other long and loud, each with an arm outstretched and a finger pointing at the hole, they went back in the house together, grumbling.
Keep in mind that everywhere they looked, they found more or less the same thing.

God only knows how they toiled to clean and disinfect the house, especially since it was so difficult to find help in those days. I have no idea how long they had to camp there, settling in for better or worse, and replacing, little by little, doors, furniture, and utensils with money lent by Agnese.

On top of it, the disaster pointed to another vexing issue. Perpetua, by dint of inquiring and questioning, snooping and sniffing around, had come to find out that some of her master’s household goods, which they had thought the soldiers looted or destroyed, were instead safe and sound in the homes of their fellow villagers. She nagged her master to go after them, and retrieve what belonged to him.
But you could not have touched on a more sensitive subject for Don Abbondio, since his things ended up in the hands of rascals, the very people he tried hardest to appease.
“What if I don’t want to hear another word about it?” he said.
“How many times do I have to tell you that what’s gone is gone?
Do I have to be nailed to the cross because my house has been robbed?”
“If it were up to you,” answered Perpetua, “you’d let them carve your eyes out.
It’s a sin to rob from others, but it’s not a sin to rob from you?”
“I can’t believe my ears,” replied Don Abbondio. “Will you please shut up!”
Perpetua held her tongue, but not for long, and she would take every opportunity to start up again.

Eventually the poor man had to stop complaining every time he found something missing right when he needed it. Otherwise—and more than once—he’d have to listen to her say, “Go and ask the person who has it, who wouldn’t have kept it this long if they’d had to answer to a real man.”

Another, sharper source of apprehension was rumors that deserters were passing by every day, just as he had suspected, which kept him in a constant state of panic that one man or a whole company might show up at his door—the first thing that he had ordered repaired, and that he kept securely locked. Thank heavens, this never happened.
No sooner had this fear subsided, however, then another one arrived to take its place.
At this point we will take our leave of the poor man, for there is much more at stake than his personal fears, the troubles of a few villages, or a temporary disaster.
